reviews.review_text: You have to admire a game with ambition. Unfortunately, sometimes, a game shoots for the moon and misses – a game with incredible ambition just may not have the budget or staff to fully realise those ideas, but you have to give credit to a developer for trying something a little different.   E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy does not shoot for the moon. It hammers together a death laser from twigs and spunk and accidently blows up an orphanage. This game was sold to me as “Warhammer 40000 meets Deus Ex”, but really that does not do this game justice. Everything about E.Y.E is completely and irredeemably mad.   Things start as they mean to continue. The game immediately asks you to create a character with a baffling recombinant genetic system – various genes are spliced together to form a statistical framework for your character, with absolutely no indication what the various stats might be used for nor how they’re calculated. This quickly becomes a running theme throughout this game, as you’re dumped into the universe with absolutely no clue what is going on - either in the games utterly labyrinthine underlying system, or in the bonkers story that surrounds it.   You play a cyber-knight wizard from a monastic order of Space Templars – immediately familiar territory for fans of Games Workshop, though there’s definitely an underlying layer of French surrealism that goes beyond the weirdest nonsense dribbled out of Nottingham. From what I can gather from the largely gibberish story, you are trying to topple a poorly defined federation, as well as dealing with a schism in your order which has lead to cyber wizard infighting. You also conveniently have amnesia, or cyberbrain damage, or something, though in a break from tired tradition everyone treats you like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ whenever you ask any questions you should blatantly already know.   There’s also monsters that come from, or are maybe made out of something called the meta-streumonic force. This force seems to give you psychic powers (because of course it does), but is otherwise unexplained. It mainly serves to add a bit of enemy variety, though considering how annoying these monsters are to fight, you might wish the developers hadn’t bothered.   E.Y.E. is an RPG/shooter hybrid, one that takes heavy influence from genre luminaries Deus Ex and System Shock 2. The abilities and equipment available to even a starting character is surprisingly vast. In addition to the expected cybernetic upgrades, there are also psychic powers – you begin the game with the ability to clone yourself three times, which in addition to giving the enemies more targets also have an admirable level of firepower, though they appear to have graduated from stormtrooper marksmanship academy. Most characters will choose to specialise as the higher levels of psychic powers, cybernetic upgrades and weapons are only available to characters with an appropriately high stat. Unusually, every stat is useful, and it is quite possible to make a “jack of all trades” character without gimping yourself.   The actual missions are a hectic, sprawling and confused affair. The mission maps are absolutely enormous, and there are multiple ways to complete a mission with various styles that are effective. Combat wise, a character based on hacking and cyberwear might use his cloak to close , drop a drone and hack an enemies brain, whereas a psychic knight might teleport (well, telefrag) about the battlefield cleaving up enemies with the preposterously powerful melee options. Enemies respawn and mill about the place, and unfortunately are ridiculously accurate over long distances – early characters can often find themselves turned into cyber mulch before they even work out where fire is coming from. This can make a sniper weapon even for close range beatsticks an unfortunate necessity.   The ways in which characters can complete objectives are also rather varied – hackers gain a variety of optional shortcuts, and most missions give you two or three ways to deal with a problem, including a diplomatic path. Now would be a suitable time to bring up the game’s dialogue, which is without exception mental. I’m not sure whether it’s a translation issue or the script was just this mad to begin with, but NPCs seem to switch characters multiple times throughout any interaction – a stoic character that starts out your best friend may become incredibly aggressive for no reason, or regress into surfer lingo. That last part is not a joke. In all honesty this just adds to the surreal atmosphere, and whether it was intentional or not it’s certainly entertaining.    What is not entertaining is the way in which this game deals with death. I appreciate that there needs to be a penalty for failure, but this game is needlessly punitive and it very nearly soured me on the whole experience. Every time you die, there’s a chance you will gain a fatal injury – which vary from a minor to an enormous permanent stat decrease. Some of these are the equivalent of losing two or three whole character levels – and considering most people will finish the game at around lv25, this is not a small issue. There is a karma stat that influences the likelihood of these injuries occurring, but I never worked out what influenced it – it seemed to go up and down entirely randomly. A few early mistakes can forever cripple a character, and even with a VERY late game way of removing these injuries it feels like a very poorly thought out mechanic.   However, if you can put up with the rough edges, there’s definitely an intriguing game buried in amongst the madness. You might not love E.Y.E, but you will certainly remember it – and that’s more than can be said for some games with a hundred times its budget.

It's hard to know where to start with a game like Divine Cybermancy, a game with more ideas in the first hour than most franchises.  It's a shooter, so conceptually it's pretty simple: you click on things, and those things can generally be trusted to die when you've clicked them enough. But Streum On Studio has so many twists for the tired formula that the end result is barely recognizable, in no particular order: bullet parrying, summoning, real-time hacking, superpowers, non-linear levels, randomized objectives, real-time research, insanity, permanent debuffs, full difficulty control, spellcasting, cyber demons, augmentations, classes, PVP, and of course the old source standby prop killing. I could write a wall of text on any of these, but instead let's take an example. I was going through the campaign co-op with some pals, and at one point we had to seize a Federal scrambler, currently under control of a looter group. Mars was quite the war zone at this point--something we hadn't kit for--so by the time we finally reached the objective we'd lost most of our resurrectors to chopper attacks and were hurting bad. Despite our best efforts, negotiations with the hackers broke down and I had to try to hack it myself, which is fortunate because I'd rolled hacker for this character. It looked like a tough hack, but nothing to worry about. Worst case, the scrambler hacks me and I hack myself free before trying again. It turns out there's worse than being hacked, something I discovered when I failed the attempt and promptly exploded, consuming our last resurrector and putting an end to our comedy of errors. I blamed the party for trying to rush me, but still made a point to invest in my cyber brain more seriously.  As you can see, there's a lot going on in the world of cybermancy; this is both the game's greatest strength and weakness. On the one hand, you can kill people with your healing syringe. On the other hand, you have no way to heal until you figure out the research system and actually get one. The price of depth is complexity, and this has to be the most impenetrable shooter I've ever played. Let's try and break it down: at its most basic level you have a very cyberpunk tactical shooter, think SMOD: Tactical meets Human Revolution. Now add Warhammer type melee weapons with ability to block bullets and complementary magic powers to go fast, summon allies, teleport, and whole lot else. There's also the obligatory cybernetic augmentations to wallhack, godmode, cloak, see sound, etc.   But unlike those games, there's a comprehensive leveling system, which manifests itself in several ways. But before I explain what it is, I should be very clear on what it's  not . It's not WoW/Everquest/Division where the battle is decided from the first moment by who has the bigger numbers. While a higher level confers certain advantages, it's still first and foremost a high-lethality FPS. So what is it? It's three systems working in tandem. First is the generic leveling template: kill and accomplish objectives to get XP to blah blah blah you could finish this in your sleep. Second you have an augment-alike system where you can choose from a selection of cyber limbs to augment for a sum of brouzoufs (currency), improving the related stats along with some more technical benefits. Cyber arms to become stronger, a cyber reflex system to dodge attacks and move/attack faster, a cyber skull to prevent headshots, etc. My personal favorite is cyber legs, which let you go (very) fast and jump higher than most buildings are tall. The third and most interesting system is that of research. Every enemy has a chance of dropping a briefcase, which contains the information for a cryptic research. Research can be started from any time ingame by bringing up the respective menu and paying the brouzouf requirement. The research continues in the background for a set amount of time depending on how many brouzoufs were committed, and when it completes unlocks a thing. The research is system is intentionally quite opaque: researches don't have explanatory names or descriptions and it's impossible to know what benefits they'll confer until  after  the research completes. Some research also requires other researches finished as a prerequisite, and the best researches have many such prerequisites. It's a great system, one that works exceedingly well to reinforce the game's mystery, something this game has in spades but more on that later.  Take all this and drop it in huge, non-linear maps. Each map can be explored in its entirety from the start and enemies' spawn depends on your location. This is great because it adds significantly the dynamism of the levels and with it the replay value, perhaps Cybermancy's single strongest point. Every level can be replayed as a side mission, but instead with randomized objectives so that each play is its own unique experience. Add to this a fairly granular difficulty control and you have the chocolate to the maps' peanut butter. Namely respawn rates, reaction time, sight and sound detection, and accuracy can be configured. It's not great, but it's leagues above most of its competitors, the sad state of affairs that is. The downside is that there aren't that many levels in the game proper, about a dozen or so total. This wouldn't be a problem--the game supports custom levels--but for whatever reason the mapping community hasn't stepped up. So while the replayability is remarkably high, but you can expect to replay the same maps quite a few times. Again not as good as it could be, but better than the overwhelming majority of AAA releases.  Now If you've heard just one thing about this game, it's probably that it's bat-ｓｈｉｔ insane. Indeed this is undoubtedly the single strangest game I've seen since LSD Dream Simulator, yet here it adds immeasurably to the charm of the game. You're dropped unceremoniously in the middle of the action, left to pick up the pieces and figure out what's going on. The game seems to delight in your confusion and very pointedly goes out of its way to never really explain what's going on. You'd think that a game being intentionally obtuse would be a major point of criticism, but honestly I quite like it. It lends the whole thing a very alien, almost dreamlike quality that works exceedingly well in context. I'd love to say more, but we're venturing awful close to spoiler territory as is. Suffice to say it's half-past the future and you're fighting the man in a cyberpunk dystopia that spans the stars and if you want anymore than that you'll have to beat it out of me.  Like all decent cyberpunk games, Cybermancy makes an attempt at world-building and while I want to say the results are hit-and-miss, that's really not accurate. It's more like hit-and-didn't-shoot-out-of-budget. It's pretty evident Streum On wanted to make a huge living world but they ran out of money long before they could deliver. On the one hand, the maps are all gorgeous and bursting with personality in their architecture and such-like design, but on the other hand they're confusing ghost towns. About the only NPCs that aren't enemies are quest givers/targets, there's almost no obligatory background reading to be found, and numerous maps have strange and strangely empty dead ends that seem to exist as little more than monuments to cut maps. To its credit it's something I never really notice while I'm killing feds, but there is still a very palpable  lack .  In summary, Divine Cybermancy is one of the strangest games I've ever played. While that alone should be enough to recommend it, the excellent co-op tactical shooter, leveling system, replayability and sheer mind-numbing depth are more than enough to justify its purchase. The insanity is just the cherry on top. The game is far stronger in co-op than single-player, so bring a couple friends along for the ride.  And  always  check your legs before moving out.
The tutorial menu has a tutorial video showing me how to get to the tutorial menu and watch tutorial videos.  My Legs are OK.

E.Y.E. is unlike anything you will ever play.  Let me start out by saying this game is VERY confusing, even with tutorials you will still be lost. It took me quite awhile to understand the basics of the game. Any ailiments you encounter remember to press C, it is a life saver.  The game is set in a futuristic cyberpunk world, with some very impressive levels, Great care and love was put into this games setting. Half of the time playing I would set there being in awe, the city levels in particular are gorgeous.  The gameplay itself is where the game really shines, nothing is more satisfying than cutting an enemy with a sword only for them to explode into pieces. Any enemy you killed gains you brouzoufs, which can be used for different upgrades or can be used for research to increase your stats.  One of my main gripe is the hacking part of the game, nothing about it was enjoyable which can lead to some frustrating encounters. If you failing hacking your character can be killed, so you have to watch your hp all the time.   If you can look past some of it's problem, you've got a real hidden gem on your hands.

When I first read the reviews for this game, I assumed I would end up either playing a barely coherent, glitchy mess that one can only squeeze a mote of enjoyment from due to its inherent jank, or I'd get a barely coherent but functioning game that gets a passing grade only because of how much effort went into it.  Neither of these scenarios ended up being the case. What $2.50 bought me is one of the strangest, deepest FPS RPG hybrids I've ever played, and I've only put 15 hours into it so far. I've dug up inches of dirt in the face of a mountain. On some level, I expected a Deus Ex like experience, and on some level, I got that. I also got Half Life, Ghost in the Shell, Warhammer 40k, and the ocassional feeling of Goldeneye, all while on what seems to be a quest to reach nirvana. This game is everywhere, and somehow it works. There's almost nothing I can say that hasn't been said before.   The story isn't even something I can get into. Without a doubt, everything about this game is something that feels rewarding when the player discovers it, and that's just it - the player has to discover everything. If you came here looking for a game that tells you a story, you've come to the wrong place. You have to beg this game to give you its story, and when it does, it'll give it to you in the form of legends, hearsay, and double talk. The sense things make is the sense you give to it.   The enemy AI is surprisingly intelligent and offers up a challenge not in terms of firepower, but actually acting like humans would in a real firefight. They take meaningful cover and fire back aiming to kill. Think you're about to sneak past someone? You better have found a way to be invisible and make not a sound, or else someone is giong to notice you. Likewise, your AI allies don't suddenly become bumbling morons, but can quickly end up taking out just as many or more enemies than you. Sprinkle friendly fire on top and suddenly everything feels very hectic and realistic.   That's something that really sticks out to me - despite the subject matter, everything feels strangely realistic, while also staying firmly in the uncanny valley. The levels are massive and sparsely populated, but filled in from corner to corner. That being said, it still lacks something... even though it's gritty and grungy and obviously lived in, it doesn't feel 'alive'. There have been instances where I wanted to stop playing the game because things were getting just a little too uncanny, like the worlds in an N64 game - that kind of feeling. The very dated and strange looking NPC models don't do much to take away from that, but it almost feels like the surrealism is intentional.   And did I say the levels are massive? Supermassive might be a proper term for it. There's FPS games that lead you down a hallway, and there's FPS games with multiple hallways, and then there's E.Y.E. There's what feels like miles of terrain that go almost entirely unused, or connect actually useful areas of a map to each other, adding to the realistic feel, even if it sacrifices convenience in most areas. The best I can equate it to is like going to Wal-Mart to buy bread, and then walking to the tire section. Duh, nothing you came for is going to be there, but there's something nice about knowing that the area is fleshed out enough to have that tire section.  And hey, the more you discover, and the longer you play, the more you'll be looking everywhere but the bread aisle for the bread you so desperately want. You'll make visits to electronics and family planning, hoping for the day that you may find the special bread that they only stock in those departments.
Where's E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy 2?

E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is unlike anything you will ever play. Despite my relatively short playtime, it's one of the most memorable games I've played in a long, long time.  E.Y.E. has fantastic world design, extreme depth in its mechanics, and extremely well done core game mechanics, but it's also user-unfriendly, unpolished, and some of the text appears to be some sort of almost-English language. It has more quality content than most games on the market, even full-priced $60 games, but for nearly every good piece of content in the game, there's some factor that just makes you scratch your head.  Both as a shooter and as an RPG, E.Y.E. have a very well-designed core. It allows you to build any kind of character, from a high-tech, heavily augmented super-hacker to a nimble assassin, a cloaked sniper to a heavily-armored living tank, from a berserker wielding explosive katanas to a psychokinetic mage who can telefrag people at will while your clones distract enemies. And each of these builds, and all the builds in-between, can be tuned and tweaked to your liking.  There are no class limitations or restrictions, so long as you can plan your stats for what you want to use. These classes are defined by your stats you gain by leveling up, your research you commit to with items you find in the field, and your cybernetic augments that you graft onto yourself as you progress through the game.  However, despite the fundamentals of this system being brilliantly done, in practice, there are some builds which are far less practical than others. While being a mind-hacker or psionic mastermind may be very appealing, they are ultimately far less practical than a simple soldier with good guns, or a melee fighter with enough accuracy for an anti-armor handcannon. Fortunately, playing E.Y.E. as purely a shooter, with no bells and whistles attached, is still a great time, but this may disappoint players that were hoping to jump into a first run with one of these builds.  More straightforward builds will lead to a better experience for two reasons: difficulty of use, and utter non-information on the complex mechanics of certain builds. The difficulty comes from some builds giving you limited to no ability to directly fight enemies, leaving you with a lack of XP sources to improve yourself further. This is particularly egregious with hacking, as hacking an enemy takes longer, is less effective, and grants lower XP, and gives less money than just shooting the enemy in the first place would. And the greatest shame here is that almost every build in E.Y.E. is an absolute blast to play; it's a ton of fun. Some builds just don't give you the resources you need to reasonably progress like others do.  The other problem with certain builds is that they aren't well explained. The first sign of this problem comes in the form of a tutorial system that's better off ignored with how poorly implemented it is. The in-game tutorial shows you how to run, jump, crawl, climb ladders, etc., all things you should already know. But the fine details are left to videos in a menu. The predominant limitation, however, comes from extremely vague descriptions of items and abilities, leaving you to occasionally guess at what things do. When fundamental, build-defining skills can't be identified without being told, there's a serious problem. Fortunately, many of these issues are front-loaded, and after a couple of hours, explanation issues taper down to a tolerable level.  Speaking of incomprehensible content, the Research in this game is more of a crapshoot than anything if you don't look up a guide. Without researching it ahead of time, I couldn't tell you what my reward was for researching 'UbiCosif Substance', or 'Alpha Bio Optical Connex'. According to tech trees, some of the research  actually does nothing .   ================================  So far, this review sounds pretty harsh. I mean, it must seem odd that I'm recommending a game with such glaring issues, right?  Well, the pros, in my opinion, outstrip the cons.  The world and levels are wonderfully crafted, with obvious attention to detail being put into the atmosphere of the world. The levels are extremely large, allow you to approach objectives in any way you can imagine, and are very non-linear, with each zone feeling more like a mini-sandbox than a mission in a campaign. And it accomplishes this with completely procedural enemy placements, and occasionally with procedural objectives, and it  works  so well.  The atmosphere is spot-on, with the entire world being filled with cybertech and dripping in environmental storytelling. In fact, the environments tell better stories most of the time than the actual story. While the graphics are somewhat dated, the designs are wonderful, and the game stands up in its own gritty, dystopian sort of way.  The gunplay is also some of the best the Source engine has to offer, with every weapon giving just the right amount of feedback. The sounds for each one are unique and have fantastic bass and reverb, with the gunfire being just as deadly as the sounds would entail. Additionally, there's variety without excess, and each weapon ends up feeling unique, like there's a role for everything you could take with you.  Melee weapons are equally satisfying, and a nimble brawler can be just as entertaining, sidestepping blows and covering space rapidly to slash targets with dual katanas, or chopping up crowds with a sword that makes people explode. Even magic powers feel great to use, with skills that make enemies violently explode into blood fonts, or even the power to clone yourself, all backed up by equally great sound design. Even the aforementioned hacker can be engrossing in its own way, with a few well-placed hacks driving enemy squads into two warring halves while you simply watch from afar. And the hacking is very fun, and an example of a minigame done VERY right, with some strategy and quick thinking required to break enemy defenses.  The A.I. is also better than people give it credit for; on higher difficulties, enemies will be aggressive, flush you out with grenades, try to surround you, or even try baiting you into a bad position. It's not excellent, but when you crank the spawn waves to 'Invasion' level, these small additions can really have an impact on your survival in the long-term.  ================================  While the world is well designed, the plot is really fairly hit-or-miss. Some people love it, some hate it. It's very much a cliche storm, but it's so cheesy that I personally can't help but love it. You're part of a militarized secret society in a civil war fighting a totalitarian government, demonic supermonsters based on humanity's dark sides, and roaming bands of looters. There's at least three MacGuffins and up to five betrayals possible in E.Y.E.'s story, and it's fantastically stupid.  On top of that, the localization for this game is hilariously bad. While there is a fan patch that un-Engrishes the game, the stilted, strange speech and swear-storms the characters get into could add to or detract from the experience. For the most part, this doesn't interfere with gameplay, so I won't list this as a negative; it's more up to preference. In my first run, I was only stuck one one objective to 'Realign the Parabola', and even that was solvable within a few minutes. For those that don't like the transration, fortunately, everyone speaks in a made-up verbal language that works well with the environment, so thankfully, nobody's vocalizing the dreadful text.    Verdict
Its like if the writers of Deus ex had to write a script for system shock 2 while really really high but set it in the 40k universe, Also everyones french.
I have no clue on what's going on. It's great.

Game turned me off at first with its unintuitive UI, mechanics, and strange setting, but once I got used to all that the game became immensely satisfying. Gunplay is actaully really solid and the story while weird is intriguing when you figure it out. Loved the deep RPG mechanics and the multiple paths you could take throughout the campaign and the game highly encourages replayability and trying things out differently which is great. Very fun to be a badass cyborg/knight/psychic/ninja.  Liked this game a whole lot. Highly recommend it to anybody that loves FPS/RPGs that gives you lots of freedom to play however you want. It's like a surreal French Deus Ex mixed with Warhammer 40k mixed with Jacob's Ladder (the movie).  This game also gets huge bonus points for having the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ CYBERDEMON FROM DOOM as an enemy type!
Worth every Brozouf.
My legs are OK.

'Hey, I just finished E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy!' Did I? Everyone who did a playthrough will know what I'm talking about. So, my second time is still to come but I completed one complete possible storyline or how you might call it. So what is this game like? [Note: You can still read my very first impression at the very bottom.] One word that describes it - many might agree: 'Strange.' Well, that doesn't say much though it really is the case with this game. It has an overwhelming feel to it - this is the case for the writing, the style and the gameplay. Though you don't necessarily have to sink into this universe and can just scrap the surface (gameplaywise and storywise) I recommend to take your time with this game. It pays off. Much has been said so I will just list some things I find worth mentioning to give you an impression:  - Art/Style: Set in a Sci-Fi-dystopian world with an asian touch - it feels like a...well...futuristic, steampunk chinatown universe at times. - Music: What shall I say, this creates atmosphere at it's best. - Gameplay: Confusing right from the beginning as it's a blend of FPS with deep RPG-similar mechanics. Your possibilities range from Research, to classic leveling up to some sort of skill tree etc. At the very beginning you can pre-customize your character in the way intended. It may be decisive if you want to choose a certain approach like stealth, hacking, combat etc. The maps are huge and you get lost pretty easily - one might criticize that. Also the level design isn't the best at times. The campaign is loosely structured with somewhat missions - each has its specific main goals and possible side-goals you may want to achieve or not, you can progress though without caring. From time to time the interaction with the NPCs will let you or force you to make decisions that affect your playthrough experience. - Other feature worth mentioning: This game is 'circular' in it's very best sense - multiple playthroughs intended, there is no real ending as there is no real end (storywise, gamewise). Replayability: 100%  ________________________________________________ This is a very very first impression comment on the game and I just want to share one thing with you guys because it's something remarkable for me as a gamer: It was the first time after a long period of FPS-gaming time that holding a gun in my hands evoked some kind of feeling. It just felt fresh and astonishing and I can't explain why. Well, there is something more to it. There has been a lot of talk about shooters and immersion and experience. Immersion - there you go.  (I will elaborate on this after I progress in the game. For now - there has already been talked about the cyber-steampunk setting with the asian touch a lot as well as the soundtrack and so on. Go have a read if you like.)

It's been a while since I last reviewed a game on Steam - or anywhere else for that matter - and to break this trend I decided to write up some of my experiences with the things I've been playing. As a bonus, I will try to make use of the text formatting that has been introduced by Steam in the meantime.   Introduction

So let's try writing some review for these games I have. Anyways,  E.Y.E. You're a stupidly wierd game.  Good: The gameplay is fun for what it is, and I never got tired of the cool factor of being able to block machine gun fire with my sword or being able to hack into someone's skull to make them explode. Couple of other gadgets you start with too, and you have quite a few upgrades and new guns you can get that may or may not be fun to use. It never really gets painfully hard either, which I consider a redeeming factor for this incoherent game.  There are plenty of free missions and locales that you can play, several fun to use weapons, pyschic powers, a campaign that doesn't overstay it's welcome, and an awesome atmosphere that is both tense and unsettling. The entire setting has a nice cyberpunk feel to it, and there's plenty of cool factor to spare.  Bad: If you are expecting any kind of story to enjoy than good luck. Confusing English and a lack of explanation makes the story hard to follow at best. It doesn't help that the story plays with some insanity tropes as well; making things even more confusing. The rpg mechanics are worthless, and I never really felt like I became anything special aside from just a samurai guy. Some of the systems like magic/psychic power feels underdeveloped, and the insanity thing, which actually is an interesting mechanic for the game, can be removed by an 'upgrade'. As far as combat goes: the A.I. is ridiculous. One little detection can result in the entire enemy army walking in a straight line towards your location. There is also this weird critical hit/negative hit system, but I've killed enemies in one hit with a 'Failed Attack' several times so I don't know what to make of that. Overall, The whole thing just feels marred by poor design choices.  The story is confusing as a story can get. The core rpg mechanics lack complexity. There are way too dang many large empty areas. A.I. is clumsy at best. And you'll probably go through the whole game without buying or upgrading anything. Don't expect to be impressed anywhere here; there's just a lot of boring trash beneath a paper thin shine.  Overall: It's a game you have to play simply for the experience. Just to play for the overall unique strangeness of the setting. To get sucked in to the weirdness of the story about a cybernetic super samurai who may or may not be insane. It has it's cool moments to help things a long too, and to say again, you start with a sword that can block pretty much anything and sets people on fire.  But, if you are expecting a solid experience then you probably won't be amused by this at all. The game requires you to overlook a lot of problems. This thing is completely strange. It's a source engine shooter that has an 'A' typical dystopian cyberpunk setting blended with Warhammer 40K with a bit of French VO. You are given a smorgasbord of powerful weapon options from the get go in the tutorial. There are a multitude of separate character upgrade paths that are impenetrable without some research (including research as one of the paths). Missions are semi-labyrinthian style maps with re-spawning enemies. Some are huge. You can alter the difficulty AI, and respawn rates in the options on the fly at any time. There is no manual save...auto save by way of a character profile. You can take your character online, offline, coop, and in-between independent from the single player campaign. There's a hacking mini-game with 4 different starting options and an additional layer of 5 options during the hack. There's over a dozen Cybernetic upgrades and implants and PSI powers (like Magic) on top of all that. It is a bit overwhelming with so many options.   The game isn't without its host of problems but suffice is the say I love games that confuse me and challenge the norm. Recommended if you want something woefully different.

EYE is a source engine game, meaning you'll find the playstyle reminicent to that of Half Life, Left for Dead, etc. But that's just the tip of the iceberg as far as gameplay goes because on top of being a FPS, this game also has RPG elements. You have stats that benefit your melee damage, accuracy, hacking, run speed, Psychic powers, and so on. On top of that you can spend ludicrous amounts of money to get cyber body modifications or to preform research on artifacts which will boost your stats even higher. At a certain point you will be able to run at ridiculous speeds, turn your foes into a fine red mist with a cybernetic claymore, and backstab helicopters with warhammers.  However there are a few places where it, debatibaly, falls short. There are a lot of bugs in the game, not including the ones that you can shoot. Even with an extensive ingame tutorial a lot of gameplay mechanics are somewhat unclear. Every character in the game talks and swears like a grizzled bandit, from actual grizzled bandits to your fellow psychic space illuminati assassin paladins. A karma and rating system that 'somehow' are intregal to gameplay probably. Getting shot in the face so hard that it breaks your legs, you get the idea.  The story is an absolute trip, even if you do get the final ending there's a lot that you probably wont grasp. With elements such as alternate/nonexistant timelines, internal conflict in past-present tense, and the psychic force of the universe lashing out in the form of monstrosities in retaliation to rapid cyberascension and the squelching out of other species. I honestly have no idea what's going on and neither will you. Shut up and gain brozouf.

Up is down, and down is up. Left is right and right is wrong, you dream while conscious and the wall between reality and daydreams becomes thinner and thinner with each passing hour. You think you know who you are, what you are, when you are and if you are, but you're wrong about all of that. Or are you? You're not very sure, because maybe you bought this game thinking it was just going to be Deus Ex with multiplayer. What you think might be a story is a distant fog you can't quite grasp, and treading through it only gets you lost. You don't know who you are, what you are, where you are, when you are or even if you are. All you know is that you're playing a game with fantastic gunplay, awesome psychic skills, multiple interesting possible playstyles, many long-term consequences and it just leaves you begging to come back for more. Not to mention the extra difficult levels to truly test your skill, and not to mention, potentially 32 person multiplayer. But this game is complex, and may not be for you. You may simply not be able to grasp it, but you have to try. This game is utterly fantastic. And for its price, absolutely worth it.

Intricate and ridiculous, EYE has earned every wise word spoken for it. It may also subvert every wise word spoken against it, even mine.   EYE is not a success, and it is not always fun. On optimized systems you can expect protracted load times and glaring proofs of the Source engine's age. Much is amateurish; little thought seems to have gone into refreshing whatever was borrowed from Source assets (namely physics and other special effects. In EYE, your hand is the Gravity Gun). And you may be unimpressed by the character models, and sickened by the abrasive sound effects and voices, and the ugliest browns and greens you've ever seen.  You will be tested. Here EYE hints that some of its flaws are not accidental, that they fit into a larger scheme. Perhaps you have played Pathologic, or STALKER, that other difficult game about acronyms. You have a suite of weapons with no clear utility and you will have to work for an hour to figure out which ones are useful. You have all sorts of abilities, but they are also spotty, and finding a way to even use them will take you at least one minute. You begin play with a rough idea that you can improve' by spending resources on various things, some of them new weapons, some of them abstract representations of the things you can do. You may or may not figure out a plot; you may or may not sort out an efficient way to become better using one of two unexplained single-player game modes, or to become functionally better (as in more skilled) using the insane multi-player game mode.   When a game puts up one kind of road block, who would I be to assume its other obstacles are accidental? I would have to be some kind of games journalist. I know that I am no kind of games journalist, because all deep questions recede as soon as I do the thing EYE most enthusiastically invites you to do: commit thoughtless virtual murder using a toolkit too large for my IRL kitchen. I blew up a man with a handgun called The Bear Killer today. I then hacked a computer in his friend's brain and compelled his friend to kill their remaining friends. I then summoned three psychic clones of myself to kill the confused survivor. Some mutants came, and I murdered them, too.   EYE: Divine Cybermancy gives you all of these gifts, but it taxes you. Somehow, this feels thematic: when it is as easy as Hell to disappear a million mutant men with a single shotgun, the real antagonist might be getting *into* it in the first place.   I sense deep genius, and complex fun. EYE makes you compromise for pleasure. When you ask why it might, you see that it wants you to think - but only for as long as it takes to reload.

E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy is definitely one of the most fun and innovative games I’ve ever played. Set in a futuristic cyber/steampunk world, you play as a member of the secret society called E.Y.E. A special society trained in using psi powers and other high tech gadgets to accomplish their mission. E.Y.E. is a top notch FPS/RPG game that allows for multiple styles of game play and plenty of character customization. You can go guns blazing, take the stealthy approach or even hack into your enemies and control their every movement. You are also in possession of a huge arsenal that carries machine guns, snipers, mini guns and even grenade launchers. With all these things at your disposal, you know this game has an amazing replay value to it. You can also go co-op with up to 16 players and wreck havoc upon the open world maps. It’s a refreshing and addicting title that I think everyone should pick up.

Firstly, the concept is amazing. Kind of like a cross between Warhammer 40K (as has been said before), Blade Runner, Dune, Total Recall, Equilibrium, and probably a few other classics I can't think of right now, with a lot of original - and borrowed, stuff on the surface and underneath, including paranormal phenomena, cyberpunk and genetic body mods, hacking, genetic manipulation for basic skill boosts/affinities, and futuristic Rastafarianism. The quintessential Sci-Fi nerd's game, IMO.  There's a money system for investing in physical/cybernetic enhancements and weapons, and research toward the same, all funded by things like bounties, hacking bank computers, and lump-sum mission completion rewards. There's also a skill point-based leveling system with lots of options for specialization, e.g., stealth, brute force, finesse, faster/greater health/recovery, athletics/acrobatics, psychic control/telekinesis, hacking enemy machinery/weapons - even their brains to do your bidding (but watch out, you may get hacked if they're better than you!), et al.  Some say it tries to do too much. I like all of the things it does too much to agree. Granted, the dialogue seems to be poorly translated, but in a far-flung future, a significant change in vernacular isn't inconceivable. I think it adds depth, in that respect. Maybe it was deliberate. There's also a bit of a learning curve due to a clunky tutorial, but creating a couple of throw-away characters while practicing and figuring out what you like isn't at all uncommon.

E.Y.E has the strange distinction of being an FPSRPG that does not sacrifice FPS for RPG or vice versa - the gunplay is solid, but the RPG gameplay is also on par with it. The setting is also very unique with its 'neo-midieval cyberpunk' aesthetic. However, the story is confusing and there are plenty of rough edges. Something to be careful of is that this game is very much a 90's game - it will not hold your hand, almost ever. Though at the same time, this game provides a rock-solid gameplay core and unparalleled custom mechanics. You can even tweak spawning rates, mob difficulty, and AI settings in the options.  To wrap up, get this game if you want to experience a very left-field, experimental take on FPSRPG core gameplay. I highly recommend you read wikis and other resources as you play, as they make discovering this game more enjoyable than going blind. Personally, I love this game just because it's not afraid of what it is - an extremely ambitious game with rough edges.

This game is a hard game to review. I love almost everything about this game from the surreal cyberpunk atmosphere to the sick sense of humor expressed through character actions and dialogue.  Unfortunately, it isn't wrong to say this game is incomplete. It is complete as far as the developers are concerned, but it lacks a proper tutorial system, the game is generally riddled with bugs, the level design can be confusing and sometimes monotonous, and the story is utterly devoid of a conclusion. This game is not for the impatient. You really have to be willing to experiment and explore to thoroughly enjoy this game.  All of that said, if you have the right mindset and a couple of good friends to play with this game can be a blast. The story is deep and is very good overall, but it can be confusing and difficult to follow. The upgrades and leveling system can be very rewarding and the powers and abilities are very useful in certain situations. And if you have enough friends this game supports 32 player coop, so thats pretty fun.

An exceptional, standout action-shooter rpg, with a few quirks, brilliant art style, and a unique vision.  The gameplay is punchy, colorful, and varied enough that I find myself continuing to come back.  This game is heavy with customization which will create a bump in the road for some, but once you get over this initial (5 minute) hump of the menu system, you'll have yourself onto a rocking ride set in an intriguing universe.  Combat seamlessly mixes GUNS, SWORDS, and PSYCHIC POWERS, while fusing with machinery. Its a lethal combination that can be crafted to your personal taste. Hacking, Machine control, rambo-style play, stealth, super-human abilities... its all here. Whatever you want.  This game sets itself apart in art style, excellent combat, nonlinear branching story (with meaningful plot points the player can influence), and a setting/mood that REALLY takes you somewhere else.  If you take time to pick up the snippets of story and explore a bit you'll enjoy it more.  The ambient-orchestral soundtrack is peerless for games in this category.  The customization is deep and allows you to truly craft any character style you can think of.  The fact that this was an indie game made for less than $1m is stunning. The production values for a game of this type are rather high.  While lacking in extensive voice overs, I found that the quirky dialogue and text based story actually added literary charm from the game and did not detract from the main idea.  Excellent gunplay, co-op, deathmatch, cool characters, and meaningful branching story choices will create a sense of intrigue, deep moods, and powerful action.  The only thing that would stop you from enjoying this is You are tossed into the game and expected to figure it out. Please take the time (5 minutes tops) to do so. You won't regret it.  For ten bucks (I got it for $5 steam sale), its a steal. It's been almost 3 years since this game came out and I'm still playing it.  Somehow it just hits on all of the right notes. Play it. And if you do, message me for a multiplayer game.  Good job. I hope to see more updates from this studio.

A very confusing yet fun cyberpunk shooter to play. Originally playing it back during release in 2011, it was a buggy mess full of broken translations and glitches that had further convoluted the game even worse than the present version. Over time, these issues were ironed out but the game still remains a very confusing yet enjoyable experience.  This game is primary a FPS with character leveling, allowing your character to grow even stronger as you continue to play through the title. You start off as a rather weak soldier, but as both your character levels up and you gain more experience playing the game, you will end up as a cybernetic powerhouse able to take on entire groups of heavily armored enemies in both gratuitous flair and efficiency. Generally all the weapons here outside of a few are generally worth using, much like an RPG you'll unlock more weapons and equipment as you level up and earn more money.  The story is both one of the greatest and worst things in this game. This game doesn't give you all the information outright and only gives small pieces every so often and the player is expected to piece all of this together over time. This can be a turnoff for some players used to more modern games that by the end of the playthrough, there is nothing new to learn or find out even in NG+. To the players that are patient enough to piece it all together, you do get a mostly intact yet shattered picture of the game, the factions and so on.  The campaign of the game is one of the high points with this game for me. You can do the campaign both in singleplayer and in coop, and unlike what the game description says you can have up to 32 people in one campaign. It's a fairly short campaign in comparison to other games, but requires NG+++ in order to 100% the campaign. When you get a group of people together to play through the campaign, it's something magical that reminds me of playing a Serious Sam title in Co-Op mode. There are other multiplayer modes such as a CTF like mode with classes and a round based deathmatch mode for multiplayer, but the multiplayer for campaign is overall a more solid experience than these.  In short, it's a fantastic yet confusing FPS that is especially fun with friends. Typically it goes on sale anywhere from $1.00-$2.50 which is well worth it at this pricetag.

It's an atmospheric FPS RPG in which you go through missions being a badass augmented ninja, completing objectives, and taking out enemies with an array of weapons, such as pistols, machine guns, shotguns, sniper rifles, or my favorite; melee weapons. How about a sword that explodes enemies on contact eh?  You can buy stuff from the store with money gained from killing enemies, etc, and research misc items that enemies can drop, which can unlock abilities or improve existing attributes of your character.  Hacking is also an element in the game, you can do things like hack a door open, turn a turret to your side, or even hack an ATM! But if you lose a hacking minigame, you will get hacked yourself. When that happens you get quite an annoying overlay on your screen saying HACKED!, and cannot hack anything else unless it either goes away on its own, or you hack yourself to get rid of it. You can even lose a hacking battle against yourself! HACKCEPTION!  It can get frustrating at times, but for the most part its pretty fun, also its a great value for 10 dollars.

A surfeit of good ideas undone by ♥♥♥♥ poor execution. I can't think of another game which is, by turns, as awesome and awful as E.Y.E. It creates a great first impression, however, with one of the biggest and (seemingly) complex stat and upgrade systems of any action RPG out there, with lots of different unique powers to buy (invisibility cloaks, the ability to clone yourself and control enemies with your mind, etc, etc) and scores of different weapons (most of which handle pretty well).  Unfortunately, all of these good ideas can't do much to counter the game's terrible A.I., boring combat, constantly respawning enemies, erratic level design (some are well done, while others are just big empty boxes), and incomprehensible writing/storyline. So at the end of the day the game's RPG pretensions are for naught: no matter how many upgrades you buy or how many times you level up the game still plays like an amateurish, unfinished, sub-mediocre Half-Life 2 mod.

Warning: This Game is not Controller Friendly.   This may not be an issue for a lot of people, but it was an absolute deal breaker for me. Normally, when a game is listed as having Partial Controller Support, it is mostly playable with your controller and only occasionally requires you to use your mouse or keyboard. This is simply not the case with this game. There are far too many required functions to be able to map them all to a standard controller, so you will need to use your keyboard so much that even attempting to use the controller just seems pointless.  Again, I realize that this isn't an issue for a lot of PC gamers, but I feel like those who, like me, prefer to play their games wilth a controller will be disappointed with just how hard it is to play this game with one. It's too bad; this one looks like it could have been a fun cyberpunk adventure.

I purchased this game two hours prior to writing this review. I paid 99 cents for it. I've played it for less than half an hour.  In that half an hour, I walked through a portal, found myself in an ugly cave, fought an ugly beast, spent a significant number of minutes trying to understand confusing tutorials, cursed the horrible menu design, dual-wielded katanas, shot some dudes in the face, shot some more dudes in the face with a different gun after stabbing some other dude in the back, almost got killed by a sniper, leveled up some abilities, made it to a friendly temple, accidentally punched a friendly guy in the face, and proceeded to get murdered 4 times in a row while trying to figure out how to tell the exceptionally large number of people shooting at me that I didn't mean it.  10/10... would get murdered repeatedly while not understanding a single thing that's happening again.

Editing-- and am early in my 'career' into this one because it delivers.  Only a few short hours into this unique experience of a RPG / FPS, and I find myself falling in love.  There almost nothing missing, and thoroughly adds more to the genre than most (a sense of zone and melee as you will drop your gun barrel or blade low, for instance).  Interface is a little bizzare and unoccomodating at first but is a beautiful tapestry of the art theme, to which this game looks grand and psychological.  I immediately felt welcomed though with the tuturoials (wiki and community is really helpful and necessary), if not immediately challenged the dangerous world of E.Y.E. where an alien world is at the very heart of a surreal and deep plot of warring factions and hightened sense of mechanical combat.  This game came out in a good year when FPS games were starting to spread wings, and this game flew sky high, if unnoticed by many.  Recommended? DEFINITELY! For everyone? Not necessarily, I like the pace, but we pick our own poisons~ But...  if you enjoy cyberpunk, gothic / victorian themes, massive architecture, Blade Runner, Shadowrun, Warhammer, Deus Ex-like themes this game has the best and funnest features of each of these and is so pleasing to the eye.

This is some  WEIRD  game. It has  A LOT  of things that -at least- could have been done better (some may argue that they're strictly BAD, and maybe they're right). I'm not even sure why i'm recommending it actualy. Maybe because i liked it a lot, even when it left me with a sour taste in my mouth.  I'll try to give some pros and cons.  Pros (?): + Its a shooter / 'cRPG' hybrid, and a pretty messy one if you're not into some kind of RPG background, but once you get the idea, its kinda cool. + It has not the best graphics, sounds or music, and yet it gets the job done: it depicts a nasty, lonely and weird dystopic future with [Cyberpunk, Warhammer 40k, Alien, Blade Runner, Matrix, etc] elements. Cool mix if you ask me. + It has a wide variety of weapons, armor, psi powers, cyber augmentation. + The hacking minigame its cool. Hard to understand at first maybe. + Campaign Co-op + You are part of a faction within a secret order that works for megacorps against the Federation. It consists of Cyber-Psionic warrior-monks that look like Templar Knights and Samurai. YAY!   Cons (?): - It throws you into some weird as ♥♥♥♥ situation and doesn't give a single ♥♥♥♥ about you. You're on your own. Tutorial you say? Mmmm... good luck with it. Yeah, sometimes it is a good thing, but E.Y.E. fails at execution here. - The save system may be a pain in the butt. - Pretty weird / bad AI. - The level design its great... but sometimes they are HUUUUGE and E M P T Y, devoid of any sign of life. Good concept maybe, terrible execution for sure. - Poor story and background development, althoug i like it (more about this later) - You are part of a faction within a secret order that works for megacorps against the Federation. It consists of Cyber-Psionic warrior-monks that look like Templar Knights and Samurai. WTF?  I may be missing something, but you get the idea by now.  Now, one last, important and  HUGE  point: the key is the ending. All this whole mess of a game makes sense (and be warned, not necessarily a good one) when you reach the 'end'.   The actual one. After you've completed the game AT LEAST three times.    This ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ lets you wonder WTF just happened and, again, it doesn't give a single ♥♥♥♥ about you, your feelings, your expectations. Anything. And i like that. What were you expecting? This has some heavy cyberpunk influences after all! But seriously, the end demands you to think about the whole experience, something that not many games do.  So, to get this to an end, should you buy E.Y.E? Only if you can see through some far-from-perfect indie game, if you like cyberpunk, weird and not so conclusive stories. If you're in doubt, wait for a sale.

Heres da thing. Its a grass roots indie game developed by a small international studio using the source engine. This means several things: bad translation, rough presentation, bugs, and a very dated look. The game sometimes feel more like a mod to another game, then an actual game of it's own. You would be tempted to think then, that the game is rubbish. It's not. In fact, it's a blast. Because when things do come together (and they do more often then not) its a really well done piece with plenty ambitious ideas. I would warn you though, this game is not for the faint of heart or for those who expect to some level of handholding at first. This initially turned me off of the game years ago. I see now though, after sticking with it, this is a great game and if you are fan of cyberpunk-likes then I think you would enjoy it too.

Certainly not an easy game to get started with on Normal difficulty with the endless waves of enemies that will once in awhile shoot one another or at another faction, but 90% of time gang up on you if spotted. Tutorial vids are a bit of a joke, the voice acting is all in a made-up language (subtitles for all!), controls are complicated without rebinding, and the over-all feel is that of a mod and not an original, stand-alone title.   Biggest gripe I have is the 'weapon group' keybinds; every single time you start a game or load a level, they RANDOMIZE what groups they select. So one level your AR, SMG, and swords are 1, 2, 3; next level its your swords, grenades, and medkit on 1, 2, 3; level after that its your AR, grenades, medkit. It's frustrating to rely on the mouse wheel to cycle through ALL your weapons/gear when in a firefight. This is apparent with manual reloading, as its quicker (or SHOULD BE) to change weapons than to reload, especially with something like the minigun or the .50 sniper rifle. But no, unless you're a 2 guns, no gear, player, the wheel will annoy ya.   Overall, ONCE YOU GET THE THING GOING, it CAN be fun. Feels like an arena shooter with a poorly written plot. With friends, maybe more so, but solo it does get old quick, and the main campaign isn't easy to follow. Can't honestly say I recomend this game to the pick-up-and-go style players.   Fallout 3 was once described as Oblivion with Guns. E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy is like Morrowind with Guns, but only with it's complexity. So final verdict: nay.

EYE: Divine Cybermancy has you fill the boots of a special agent working with a special forces group in a world strife with political backstabbing. That said, I wouldn't consider plot to be the biggest pull to this game. Between the wide variety of weapons, hacking, psionics, stealth, and mechanical augments, the game is a veritable playground, with each mission being able to be completed in a variety of ways: Slowly hacking into the augmented brains of your enemies and turning them into mindless slaves to act as your meat shields to wearing heavy armor and mowing down hordes with a minigun, or even using psychic powers to fling broken cars across the map. Perhaps the most alluring aspect of the game is the power the protagonist can obtain, vaguely reminiscent of Deus EX, you have no conventional classes, and your progressive character building eventually results in an incredibly powerful, flexible--or specialized--protagonist. The main campaign can be played alone, or with friends on LAN, moreover, there's competitive PvP gamemodes to keep things fresh.   The game itself is fairly adequate in length, requiring six to ten hours to complete, but with endings for four complete playthroughs. Moreover, your characters will maintain from one gamemode to another, so if you play multi-player a lot, you can then port your character to the main campaign, or load it in to play with a friend in co-operative missions. As such, the same character can be made to play through the game multiple times, hitting ever high levels of power until you're jumping over apartment buildings and slicing through gunships with a Katana--that's also a demonic cyborg.  If you enjoy things like Warhammer 40k, Ghost in the Shell, or Shadowrun, this is likely the game for you with its dystopian cyberpunk FPS/RPG themes. While the plot, gameplay, and atmosphere holds up for solo play, the game is best done with a group of friends.

So, as a huge fan of all things unique and immersive, it took me forever to get around to playing this game. But honestly, this game is a highly underrated gem of any of the games I have played recently. If you have any interest in games like System Shock 2, Deus Ex, Dishonored or other immersive sims with RPG elements, this game has some huge pluses in my book.   Full disclosure: to get the most out of the story that I have experienced so far, I modded my game. I would highly recommend you do the same, as the initial translation has a reputation for being rather imcomprehensible. As of now, I have not experienced that, and the game's writing really shines when it fully explains the context of all of the RPG elements tied into the narrative of the game. It is unique in that the folklore of the world (which is beautiful, even by today's graphics standards) refers to your overall skillset quite a bit, which makes it feel a little bit more of a personal journey.   So far I am both fascinated and excited by this game, pick it up if you get the chance, and check online for some info on aspects of gameplay, the guides really help to get you excited about the prospects of your experience with the game.

Imagine creating a game with elements combined from the original Deus Ex, STALKER, and Half-Life 2. Sounds like the best FPS/RPG possible, right?  Well, now imagine that the team behind it is a bunch of amateurs instead of a AAA studio. That's EYE: Divine Cybermancy.  There are some interesting things going on here, and the beginning of the game has a pretty good hook. But it falls apart quickly.  The graphics are what you would expect from an indie shop doing a 3D game. I actually  loved  the environments - they're huge with a great sense of scale and perspective. BUT the level design is awful. Without a map it's easy to got lost in the labyrinthine twists and turns. And the quest markers can hinder more than help; you often have to walk very far in the opposite direction from them in order to make a single turn that enables you to actually get to them. It's frustrating to see where you're supposed to go but not have any idea how to actually get there.  The combat barely passes for typical FPS fare, and the guns are all quite standard. I also never figured out how to unlock new ones, so I was left using the same weapon or two for the entire game. The fact that the explanations for how things worked were very poorly written (or translated) certainly didn't help me figure it out.  The real crime is in the leveling system. You get skill points to put into stats, but guess what? They can be permanently lost. I never quite figured out exactly when or how they got detracted though. You also have cybernetic implants, but they use money instead of anything attached to getting a level up. That's a huge problem because you also need the money to use for research to unlock new abilities and to buy consumables and occasionally as bribes for quests. Having all of those things under the same currency means you never have enough to actually improve your character significantly. I didn't feel any more powerful at level 20 than I did at level 1.  You can also get stuck if you don't put enough points into hacking and related skills because in the very late game it's required that you hack a few high level objectives. The only solution for me was to grind out a several more levels and put everything I had into that one skill. It was so supremely annoying that I almost quit even though I was 90% of the way through. The developers clearly didn't learn the lesson from Deus Ex that there should be multiple ways to advance and achieve your goals.  The story was a little interesting in the beginning, but it grew tiresome. Most of the interesting parts of have to be consumed by simply reading large blocks of text. It avoids forcing the player through exposition, but in this case I would've prefered more back story within the main game over a library where all the facts are dumped into a giant pile.  The ending is intriguing. I am glad I ultimately finished it. But the game forces you to complete it three times in a row with the same character in order to discover everything that's going on. How some people slogged through that I have no clue.  I picked up Divine Cybermancy because I love the FPS/RPG genre and this seemed like a solid twist on the setting. But the system and story and level design did not live up to what I hoped for. There  is  a core of a good idea here. The game just wasn't designed well enough on top of it to be worth your time.

It's entirely possible that with a group of friends and a lack of other games to play, I could get into this, but as it stands I have so many other things that are so much more worthy of my time.  From the little I've played, gameplay is stilted - all the environments and levels are too large for how slowly you move, completely breaking the flow of the combat. Guns are vastly more effective than melee weapons, as I often died just getting into melee range. You expel the remainder of your clip when you reload, which leads me (as a compulsive reloader) to accidentally lose all my ammo. The writing is... 'poor' is an understatement. It's clearly a bad language port. No real story is given, literally every npc I met was absurdly rude to me, and it was generally just a really poor experience.

This game isn't that complex really. You pretty much have 4 or 5 options. You can be a use psy powers to summon clones or teleport into battle, you can run around with a sword and deflect bullets, you can build yourself into a cyber warrior that can jump 500 feet in the air and throw cars, you can hack enemies and atm's taking direct control and you can be a gunslinger that headshots everyone. If you want, you can also lay down turrets and send around drones that will also help kill guys for you. You can be a mix of any of those things if you want.  The game definitely has it's own lore and terminology and it really has so much going for it in a first person shooter it may be confusing.  All of that being said, the game is open, your choices send you into new stages you may never have seen, and to truly beat the game you have to beat it 3 different times allying with 3 different forces and gaining 3 different superpowered psy powers. One thing that I wasn't expecting with this game is that for the vast majority of it enemies spawn endlessly, you can customize the frequency of it but keep that in mind as it does make a difference. It's also important to note the game is incredibly insane. Seriously, it's very crazy.

A surprisingly complicated game, E.Y.E. is a cyberpunk game with large amounts of replayability and choice in your actions and characters.  The interface and controls can be complex and confusing, and I would recommend remapping them. The graphics are very good and the game itself is very well optimized. The gameplay itself offers many different ways of progressing and playing, with both charging in and stealth hacking being viable from start to finish.  I wasn't lying about it being complicated, though. Don't play the game if you want to understand everything that's going on(or even everything in your kit) quickly. It's a game that takes time and patience to understand, but it's a VERY good game.  10/10 I keep killing Guys That Look Like Me.

TURN UP THAT DIFFICULTY LEVEL AND DIE LIKE NEVER BEFORE!  EYE is what most people would call rough. That's because it is. There's practically no tutorial beyond the poorly translated and frankly laughably useless tutorial videos that are provided for the player to access THEMSELVES when they damn well feel like it. Beyond that, the games stat system, cybernetic upgrades, abundance of technology to research, cybernetic abilities, psionic abilities AND the sheer amount of money it'll cost to pay for all the prior leaves this game a mystery to the uninitiated. This is without going into the fact that the games has a massive backstory and moderate amount of plot that includes several galactic wars that resulted in the near death of humanity multiple times.  So, why am I recommending this game? Because it's cool. The game will really make you feel like your a cybernetic warrior while you're playing, at which point stats be damned. Also, multiplayer!

EYE is like a nightmare that you do not want to wake up from.  As alien as it is alienating, EYE offers an experience like no other. You take the role of an secrete militant religious organization that calls itself EYE. Due to plot reasons, you wake up with no memory for unspecified reasons.   The first thing you may realize is that the controlls were probably made by Marsians and the tutorial consists out of clips from Youtube videos explaining basic commands. It doesn't help that much of the text is poorly translated from french. After making your way out of the tutorial cave the game allows you to pick your equipment, using inventory system. The game allows all kinds of builds, from Street Samurai to Psychers, to Snipers and Heavies.  A notable shoutout is to the guy who came up with the hacking system, which is a riff on classic JRPG combat, which essentially means that the object you are hacking has as much of a chance to take over your body as you have to do their. Essentially, when you hack into a door, the door hacks into you. You may posess hacked soldiers and use them for stealth manuvers.  After loading up every square inch of your body you may begin to power through the gangs of raiders and spacemarines located in a dull industrial area. If you haven't noticed, you also have psychick powers, which allows you to create astral clones of yourself, as well as push enemies away from you, shattering their ribcage.  The interaction between all those different systems created a fascinating dynamic, which keeps one hooked for hours on end.

This game is incredibly buggy and poorly made. The concept is interesting, but terribly executed. I wouldn't recommend spending more than $2.50 on this game, if that. The dialog is awful and the level design is abysmal. While interesting and well-made in most aspects, the levels are simply too massive and maze-like with far too many dead ends that lead you deep into a temple, only to see a dead end. The tutorial consists of 'Press T and look for the video.'  The dialogue is absolutely atrocious, and there are some areas of the game that didn't get translated from French. The language barrier is very obvious at all points of the game ('I haven't enough energy') and the swearing, while at first pleasantly realistic, became tedious after watching my character curse 2-3 times in every sentence in some dialogues, with no conversation choices other than childishly calling names. Why even have a covo option system when 50% of the prompts are for one choice?  4/10, good effort, but terrible QA

An odd game that feels like a mix of many FPS RPGs before it. What it lacks in polish of a mainstream game it certainly makes up for in its openness and deep gameplay. With its large array of choices towards combat and character creation to its support for a 4 player co-op campaign; E.Y.E. certainly has a lot of charm and would certainly please any fan of FPS RPGs.

E.Y.E is a bit weird at first, given the setting. On top of that, most characters do speak russian. But it's wonderful refreshing to the 5th sequel of a well known franchise or to the 10th clone of it. The story unfolds nicely, and opens up to multiple endings.  E.Y.E may not have next-gen graphics (in fact it's Source engine, like HL2, TF2 etc.), and it's flawed and unpolished. But you get to play it the way you want, be it armed to the teeth with deadly weapons and heavy armor, a more careful approach employing sniper rifles, or you might want to hack the enemy, so you achieve your goals without getting dirty yourself.  Also, it has coop, which is eespecially interesting given that you can split the roles, so e.g. one concentrates on hacking, the other waltzes around, mowing everything down.  If you don't mind having to put up with some of the games quirks, you should give it a shot.

It is worth giving a chance I still don't fully know what I'm doing but it gets more enjoyable as you start figuring it out. I would probably recomend maybe watching a couple tutorial vids that may be out there before starting out but a pretty cool concept.

E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy has many bug, it is hard to figure the game out most of the time you have no idea what you are doing, skills, character creation etc. are really tricky. It is possible to see this game as a lost gem of early 2000s, I felt like I was playing a game from that era. The atmosphere is dark, it is really dark, like bladerunner. The lore is rich and amazing, it has a great potential. It is like a offshoot of equilibrium and warhammer 40k. Combat simply amazing, you can go gun blazing then switch to swords cut your enemies into pieces. It is simply an amazing game buy it you won't regret it.

A unique and truely open optioned experience, if slightly unintuative for people who like having everything spelled out for them.  When this game says you can play however you want, it isnt kidding. This is the first game I have seen where a healer, hacker, gunfighter, psyker , and swordsmen are TRUELY on even footing. The game also implements location based injuries well with an HP/Energy/Mental health system quite well. Inventory is also realistic to the point of WHERE you can carry something on your body, and the enemy can see your inventory if he knows where to look.  For multiplayer you can either play with friends through the campaign or go on open ended missions, which the stats you gain stay to your character for seamless transitions between multiplayer and single. The only downside is a lack of PVP, which at the time of writing I hear is in the works.  to top it all off, its on the source engine, so happy modding!

I decided to update this review now that I've put more hours into this game. Overall, E.Y.E lacks polish. There are a lot of things in the game that could be better than they are. The game is both rough and flawed, but it has character. If you can look past its faults, there is a pretty good game underneath.      The Old Review:  I'm not usually one for the FPS genera, but this game is fantastic on all counts. From its branching story line to RPG elements, this game feels like a throwback to times where a game didn't have to hold your hand the whole way through. On top of that, E.Y.E allows significant control over character build and play style, i.e. there are nearly infinite solutions to any problem you may encounter.   You see a crowd of enemies. What do you do? >Use magic?  >Check for cybernetic implants you can hack? >Turn invisible and sneak by? >Stab them with a rocket-sword? >Send in the drones? >Send in the clones? >Snipe them one at a time? >Teleport into their group and wreck havoc?  I think you understand what I'm getting at here. Espionage, corruption, and mystery will envelop you; how will you handle it?
This is one of the most complex, long and dedicated piece of work I've ever played. Trust me, if you like shooters, science-fiction, rpgs and cyber-punk, this will be your game.

EYE is a weird game, but mostly in a good way, at least once you get accustomed to its myriad confusing aspects.  The basic structure is that of an ARPG: you get quests from a hub and then go into the wilderness of the cyberpunk future to kill people, gain experience and skill points, and get money to buy more guns with. Locales range from skyscraper-lined streets to bandit-overrun hive worlds. You will encounter entire mission locales that are essentially homages to classic action films.  You will meet some very badly written characters and kill hundreds of baddies attacking you via the means of massive amounts of firepower, PSI spells and magic. Oh, and melee. This is the sort of game where you start off with a cyber-katana. It is overdone, extreme and often overkill, but enjoyably so.  There is also a hacking minigame which allows you to influence and take over everything from the mundane door to turrets and even enemies, and make them kill each other or just fry their cyberbrains. However there's a catch: the things you hack will try to hack you back. This is the only game in the world where you can be hacked by a door. There's a fair amount of variety in the types of characters you can play, from minigun-wielding tanks to sneak melee attacking invisible ninjas. Skills and augmentations can be chosen to compliment your style of play.  The main problem with the game is the lack of direction and polish. It often feels like it was made by a mod team with no project management whatsoever. Everything someone wanted to make, or happened to make, is in there somewhere. The dialogue is also incredibly bad most of the time, and even feels like no-one bothered to rewrite placeholder dialogue for the final version. Example: you will meet an NPC who will say: 'I need you to bring back some stuff for me.' Your answer choices are: 'Interesting...', and 'Sorry, you're breaking my balls.' That is the entire quest dialogue. Most characters are foul-mouthed for no reason whatsoever, it seems like whoever wrote the dialogue just thought it was cool. It does lead to a fair bit of unintended amusement though.  The game could really have done with a copywriting pass by someone with native-level English knowledge. That it was written by people with less than stellar grasp of English is often painfully obvious. There is actually a fairly interesting grand plot behind it all, but good luck figuring it out from just playing the game, as it's obscured by the writing and the disjointedness of the missions. The hacking minigame is also incredibly tedious at higher levels.  The game may be rough, but it's still a diamond, at least if you think you could enjoy a Deus Ex-inspired shoot-em-up, dice-em-up ARPG made by a bunch of Frenchmen on LSD. Oh, and if you can gather enough crazy like-minded people for it, you can play the game through in coop with up to 32 players. You don't see that every day.

A Source engine FPS/RPG that is cyberpunk in content and form. The rough-on-the-edges UI might be forgiven under the smokey atmospherics and hallucinatory story and setting. Psi-tech, the 'cybermancy' aspect, completes a trinity of gameplay along with conventional and fictional hybrid weaponry, and cyber implants, upgrades, and abilities. Enemy units have these same capabilities, turning what can seem like a simple duel into a hot zone of holographic projections, clones, bots, mind-hacking, and exploding flesh. Factions and monsters add even more chaos to combat. But it can feel like an incomplete experience; to enjoy such ambitious anarchic storytelling is a personal preference. A missions system based on the maps unlocked throughout the campaign, along with multiplayer, provide a good amount of replayability.
