TL;DR: Love it or hate it, buy it and try it! For this price it's a crime to not buy it if you're into complex RPGs, Cyberpunk and can spend time on figuring out the game.   I've bought this game around half a year ago because I liked the picture and didn't know what to expect from it. Honestly, I played it for around 26 minutes and then closed it. Now after all this time I felt like I want some cyberpunk in my cup so I thought I'd give it another go. And now I'm enjoying it! It's clear that it was made with heart and love.  Opinions about this game differ from person to person, but everyone seems to agree that it's complicated. That's pretty much true, thankfully the community has several basic guides that will help you understand what exactly the game wants from you, because it doesn't explain itself at all and when it does, it does so very ambiguosly. I'd only like to add that it's also complex. Under all the vague descriptions of classes, stats and mechanics there lies a deep RPG structure. I can say without exageration that it is the most complex RPG (albeit not the most refined) I played on par with first Deus Ex.  That's not to say that the game has no problems. Obviously the mechanics could be explained a lot better and while the tutorial helps you out, it's not a particulary well put together tutorial. Also the world feels kinda dead in some places, not sure if its intentional or not. The voice acting isn't translated into english (native language seems to be french) and what's translated with subtitles has a plethoria of grammatic mistakes and due to poor translation the dialogues sound (or read) a bit silly. Another thing I have problem with is stealth. Not sure if it's bad, I'm doing something wrong, or there is simply no stealth system, but if you make at least 1 step not crouching, the enemies that are liek 200 meters away from you behind a building will know you're there and rush towards you. If you crouch it's a bit better.  Now about good stuff. I absolutly adore the world structure and lore, as ambiguous as it may be. You won't know much unless you read the world's history in an Archive in your HQ, but at least it's there for those interested. There seems to be potentially interesting struggle between 2 organisations of same faction and your protagonist struggles between his commander and his mentor who want different outcome (which you will be a catalyst of, I assume). Other good thing I can say about the game is that the guns feel great. Like really great. They have an appropriate amount of recoil and weight. Did I mention that you can dual-wield katanas?   I could go at greater length describing this game, but this 'review' is already bloody long. Tell you what, if you don't buy it now at this sale, you basically commit a crime against yourself. Do yourself a favor and buy this amazing title instead of coke.

This FPS is infamous for its very surreal plot that starts fairly simply, then does not make sense. Indeed, it requires 3 playthroughs to get the true ending, and will probably take that long to piece the plot together. It is not that new-player friendly in that there is a lot of text backstory, and it doesn't really teach you how to play without delving into the video tutorials. That said, it is super easy to just grab heavy armor, whatever weapons suit your fancy, and just blaze through the game barely taking damage until endgame, which is pretty difficult at times. The game has its problems, such as needing a lot of grinding to get new weapon unlocks, the inventory system and other menus being really unwieldy, and silly high enemy respawn. The text is also really hard to read at times, and you'll be reading a lot, because there are no lines spoken in English. But if you like cyber-punk atmosphere combined with a mind-screw plot, this might be for you

I absolutely love this game. It has archaic design, an incomprehensible plot, and some elements of it are just plain indecipherable. But I love it. I love its atmosphere, I love its uncompromised vision of itself, and, first and foremost, I love the absolute freedom it gives you, the player. If you have to have your hand held through gameplay sequences and your story spoon fed to you, then you will hate this game. But if you've got a craving for something out of the ordinary and you have no trouble finding your own fun in a game, then you're in for a treat. This game is absolutely PC down to its core, and I love that. I hope you can love it too.

An unintuitive mess of a game.   The environment is set up to be one hell of a unique experience. Branded as 'Indie Deus Ex', - in a world where cybernetics and religion combine to create an all-encompassing 'cybermancy', you are... And this is about as far as I was able to delve into this terrible game.  Like a lot of indie games, there is very little lead in. You're kind of dropped into this game's unique world with little explanation or tutorialization, and the biggest sin of all is that this game DOES have tutorials. They're poorly named (for example, early in the game's initial stages, you're told to push T to bring up tutorials, and read the tutorial on CyberJump. Except there IS NO TUTORIAL CALLED CYBER JUMP.)  The game's lack of handholding is pervasive. The world building also falls flat in that everyone who does speak seems to speak some cyber future moon language, leaving you to read the subtitles.  Overall, this game isn't really much more than a really good idea whose implementation falls flat on its face with underdeveloped or broken gameplay and mechanics, and seriously underdeveloped storytelling.

Weird controls to get used to (re bindable, but it feels very much like the controls are designed around controller such as a quick access skill wheel but without controller support). Can be very unforgiving building your character certain ways which end up being grinding to get the right skills when certain builds no longer work. And AI that will varry from seeing you through two walls while your crouching making no noise at all, to running right by you as you crotch giving you an easy kill.  Despite the jank (and a story line that I have no clue what's going on in it other then here is objective, here is a few ways to play the early game but one of those ways becomes not viable half way through the game, go) it seems like a pretty fun game that is enjoyable reguardless the jank, though at the same time feels like if they take the basic mechanics of the game and fix the AI, controls, and make the story a bit easier to follow in another game it could go from, decent game to great game. But as it stands it feels very much like they where not sure if they wanted to make a PC game or console game and ended up making a PC game with console UI but no controller support which makes the UI that much more awkward, but still worth playing.

An interesting concept with mediocre execution. The effort of development was placed on player models and the progress system, rather than evenly spread through those two aspects, as well as level design and enemy AI. The latter two are severely lacking, and only on specific levels does the game seem interesting. Level design is a major issue; consuming the majority of a player's time sprinting through the excessively large 'rooms' and areas; even the 'HQ' is exceedingly large, tracking down some of the very select few interactive NPCs from chapter to chapter is tiresome (they move around in the HQ between chapters). Despite these drawbacks, I've found myself spending time playing this game (its most entertaining with co-op play). The leveling system, and different ways to spend your Brouzoufs (currency) is interesting: cybertech, cybernetics research, weapons and gear. The addictive elements of the game seem to have taken hint from the MMO genre.

It may take you a while to get into it, I believe I didn't really pick it up till about a year after it was in my library.  BUT HOLY ♥♥♥♥.  This is by far one of the best (modern) indie games I have ever played. Think Deus Ex meets Warhammer 40k.  A bit rough around the edges, but if you can look past that, you'll have a hell of a time.

This is an incredibly odd game. It seems to mix fantasy and cyberpunk in sort of a Warhammer 40k, mixing mythology and technology. This is basically a strange mix between Morrowind, Half-Life, and Deus Ex. And it actually works. It takes some dedication to get used to because there is an insane amount of text, and some mechanics are kind of unorthadox, blending the RPG system with the real time shooting. Still, this is absolutely worth the 10 bucks. Its like a frankenstein of different games, and it works really, really well. Somehow.

I LOVE this game!  Even with its flaws E.Y.E is a thoroughly enjoyable romp through Cyberpunk city. It's like a unique mix that someone threw together of movies: Blade Runner and Johnny Mnemonic, and games: Deus Ex, Syndicate and Hellgate London. However... The game does suffer from some bugs, bad translations and frequent crashes. I can only hope that the developers can patch up these inconveniences ASAP, and when they do, this will be a truely amazing game. Great value for money and a must have for any Sci-fi/RPG fan.

As a very informal summarization of my feelings on this game: This game is made by a bunch of people from France that know more than I do. They set out to make a game for fun rather than profit, and sure enough I have closer feelings to E.Y.E than Deus Ex, which it just so happens to feel a lot like. It has a wide variety of weapons and special abilities you can use to get through the games various challenges (and it is very challenging.)  The plot at first seems very uncreative and half-wit with lots of cussing and childish insults. However, the more time you play the game the more you come to understand the harsh world of E.Y.E and its mechanics. It certainly has a many flaws like its usually sub-par translation job, clunky UI, and up-and-down difficulty jumps. Fortuneately over some years the game has been patched to have (sort of) better translation, new UI options, and incredibly tweakable difficulty.  As 'meh' as the game was, I personally couldn't help but keeping playing it and get deeper into the story, characters, and combat. It's an alright game, certainly no triple AAA masterpiece (or as of lately to date, triple AAA flop), but it has more than enough content to burn some hours on and have fun while doing so. With that being said, its price is very generous and I'd recommend it to FPS and Sci-Fi fans.

Online Co-op with friends is frustrating to get working, but once you get past that, you engage in an entirely out of this world experience on LOTS of acid....  You will gain Brouzoufs. Your legs will break. Your legs will be okay.   Like many have said, Think Blade Runner meets Deus Ex meets Metal Gear Rising meets Warhammer 40k meets Groundhog Day. Add in about 8 U.S. ounces of pure Columbian Heroin, A few (Like, 16?) tabs of acid, or other personal favorite hallucenogenic, and then give a chimpanzee a French => English pocket dictionary.  The Result? The biggest mind♥♥♥♥ of a game you will likely ever experience. Mind you, don't take that as me saying this game is bad. The poor translation is intentional, and the dialogue will give you hours of amusement. Once you get Co-op working, have some friends nab this game on sale, and fire up a game. I can almost guarantee the results will be entertaining
